li.p: Find all the critical numbers of f. (Hint: after finding the derivative, factor out x^{-2/3}.)

For each critical number x=a, evaluate a decimal approximation of f'(x) at a number very close to a but less than it, and at a number very close to a but greater than it. Use this to determine whether f has a local maximum, local minimum, or neither at that critical number.
Suppose g is an arbitrary function that is defined and differentiable except at a finite number of points. At what kinds of points can the sign of its derivative g' change?
How could you have used your answer to part (c) to reduce the number of points you had to evaluate f'(x) at in part (b)?
Relative maximum at x=-1, relative minimum at x=1, and neither at x=0.
At points where g' is zero or undefined. That is, at the critical numbers and at points where g is undefined.
We only needed to evaluate g' at one point in between -1 and 0, and at one point in between 0 and 1.
